                        Guiana</tei-placeName>, along with a free man of color who did not file an
                    appeal in cassation. Both of his co-accused were considered slaves throughout
                    the proceedings. However, one of them, <tei-persName ref="#CJ" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Cyprien
                        Jacquard</tei-persName>, argued that he was in a state of manumission because he
                    had been bequeathed by his master to his emancipated mother, so as to provide
                    him and other children with a means of livelihood.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">When this case was first presented, the <tei-orgName ref="#CDC" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">Court of Cassation</tei-orgName> was
                    struck by the odiousness of considering a child as a slave to his mother, whom
                    she could potentially sell. It could happen that a mother was bequeathed by a
                    master to her own son, and he might also be in a position to alienate her. Would
                    such a reversal of the laws of nature be sanctioned by colonial legislation? </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The court, in a ruling dated January 10, 1834, ordered that the facts be verified
                    before making a decision on the appeal.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">As a result of the information gathered in compliance with this ruling, it was
                    found that Jacquard's mother, upon gaining her freedom from her master, had
                    received her children born of him, as well as her own mother, as part of her
                    bequest. Subsequent to Jacquard's conviction, this woman made the required
                    declarations at the civil registry office, as per the Ordinance of July 12,
                    1832, to obtain her son’s emancipation certificate.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Given this situation, the Attorney General of the colony argued that Jacquard,
                    the appellant in cassation, was not admissible to file an appeal in cassation.
                    This was because, as per the colonial ordinance of July 20, 1828, Article 9,
                    which the Criminal Procedure Code, since promulgated, does not override, slaves
                    are prohibited from using this appeal, and Jacquard was still a slave at the
                    time of the alleged crime and his conviction.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">At the hearing on June 26, <tei-persName ref="#DEH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Counselor Dehaussy</tei-persName>
                    reported on this matter and, without examining the grounds for the appeal,<tei-pb n="25" facs="v1n1p25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>denied it in consideration of the state of slavery in
                    which the appellants found themselves.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">This magistrate did not hide how distressing this situation was and how desirable
                    it was for slavery to be declared incompatible with such intimate family
                    relationships. He announced that, through his dispatch, the Attorney General
                    assured that a bill regarding this incompatibility would be proposed in the
                    session of the colonial council. However, he had not found a legal basis under
                    which the Court of Cassation could release young Jacquard from the state of
                    slavery in which he found himself.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#Parant" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Parant</tei-persName>, the Attorney General, concluded in
                    this direction, invoking the admission Jacquard had made during his
                    interrogation and the steps taken by his own mother to secure his
                    emancipation.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The admission recorded in his interrogation amounted to this:</tei-p>
                <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">My name is Cyprien, also known as Jacquard; I am sixteen years old, and belong
                        to the colored caste; I am a carpenter by profession; I belong to my mother,
                        with whom I live in <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>, where I was
                        born.</tei-p></tei-q>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The court, in a ruling dated June 26, started from this point of fact and
                    declared that there was no need to examine the merits of the appeal.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">During its discussion of the case of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">de facto</tei-emph> freedman <tei-persName ref="#Louisy" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Louisy</tei-persName>, this court had seemed to us to better
                    understand its high mission. </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">It had judged that freedom is a right and that slavery should be confined within
                    the strict limits granted it by the law, and that one should not treat as a
                    slave someone who has de facto ceased to be one. Consequently, despite the
                    colonial ordinances that obliged de facto freedmen in risk of being declared and
                    sold as slaves for the benefit of the colonial domain, to produce their freedom
                    papers, the court, focusing only on the law and the fact of freedom, declared
                    Louisy’s appeal admissible.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Was this not the occasion to render a similar ruling? Neither in Roman
                    legislation nor in the <tei-bibl type="legal" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#CN" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Code
                        Noir</tei-title></tei-bibl> (the edict of 1689) do we find consecrated such
                    immorality, by which a father or<tei-pb n="26" facs="v1n1p26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>mother can become,
                    arbitrarily, the property of their child. For, with such a doctrine, one would
                    be obliged to tolerate that they sell the authors of their days in the market
                    and receive the price. The Romans also abolished the ancient law that gave the
                    father the right of life and death over all members of his family.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The Code Noir allows for several cases where freedom results as of right from a
                    status incompatible with slavery. This includes the case where a master has
                    appointed a slave as his executor or as a guardian for his children.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">How can one reconcile the status of being a son with that of being a slave to his
                    mother? A son, according to natural law and the civil code published in the
                    colonies, is bound by duties entirely different from those of a slave towards
                    his mother.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The mother also has particular duties towards her child. If this child becomes
                    unable to provide for their subsistence, is she not obligated to nourish them?
                    And how could such a law not be above the unjust law of slavery?</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">It is regrettable that the Court of Cassation left this important question
                    without resolution and only focused on the apparent fact. By judging in this
                    manner, did it not violate Article 7 of the 1832 ordinance, which ensures that
                    those who are de facto free have the benefit of an appeal in cassation?</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In declaring that he belonged to his mother, did not young Cyprien Jacquard
                    prove, by that fact alone, that he had no master, and that there existed between
                    him and his mother nothing but the natural and civic bond?</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div xml:id="traits" id="traits" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">TRAITS OF CRUELTY.</tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">It would be a lengthy story to recount the deeds of revolting cruelty that some
                    slave owners in our colonies inflict upon the unfortunate slaves. Every day,
                    torn by the whip of the overseer, deprived of their coarse sustenance, they
                    slowly perish in incessant torment; only greed and never humanity sometimes hold
                    back these <tei-pb n="27" facs="v1n1p27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>cruel masters who fear losing a venal
                    price with the death of a slave. But when the slave, crippled or old, can no
                    longer provide the same services, when his presumed profit on the plantation no
                    longer exceeds the expenses he incurs, oh, then! No consideration can hold them
                    back anymore, and just as one breaks an old, disabled piece of furniture, so do
                    they mercilessly cause to perish the man they tore from his family when he was
                    young.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Sometimes, a whim, a resurgence of barbarity seizes a master, and no matter what
                    potential prejudice such atrocious satisfaction might possibly bring him, he has
                    a man, his peer, his equal, sacrificed. These acts of cold cruelty are so far
                    from our mores that we, born in the colonies, cannot comprehend them. Often, an
                    honorable skepticism guards us against the accounts of our correspondents. Would
                    to God that they were all false! We would be the first to proclaim them so, and
                    our hearts would not be burdened by painful impressions.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Here are two new facts to record in the long list of crimes that makes up
                    colonial history. There we not only see a colonist committing a heinous murder,
                    but another ordering it to be carried out by his slaves, thus demoralizing these
                    unfortunate individuals who, at the risk of their lives, could not refuse the
                    orders they received.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, un landowner in the
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">commune of La Rivière Pilote</tei-placeName>, apparently convinced
                    that he had reason to complain about his slave Gabriel, summoned six slaves from
                    his workshop on April 16 and ordered them to bring him Gabriel's head. The
                    slaves promised obedience.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Gabriel, unofficially informed of his master's intentions, went to see him and
                    offered 3,535 francs for his redemption. The master replied that he would
                    consider it. Although this reply was nothing short of satisfactory, the
                    unfortunate Gabriel set about realizing his funds, and went to the market town
                    of Le Marin to sell his flour. As he was leaving, six negroes ambushed him,
                    drove him to the sugar mill, tied him to a calabash tree and killed him. One of
                    the executioners then went to the owner, who, having heard the story of the
                    murder, simply replied coldly: <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">That is well</tei-emph></tei-q>.</tei-p>
                <tei-pb n="28" facs="v1n1p28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">However, the planter, having gone to the place where Gabriel's mutilated corpse
                    lay, couldn't stand the dreadful sight for long: he withdrew, and with the help
                    of his sugar maker, spread the rumor that Gabriel had been killed by a mule. He
                    sent word to the Commune's Commissar, but public rumor had beaten him to it, and
                    the Commissar came with the Justice of the Peace and two doctors to perform an
                    autopsy on the corpse. The type of death was then recognized, and among other
                    wounds, a gunshot wound to the lower jaw. A report was drawn up and deposited at
                        <tei-placeName ref="#FoR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Fort-Royal</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In the same colony, in the commune of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Macouba</tei-placeName>, a wealthy
                    owner was accused by the public of killing his slaves. The public prosecutor
                    went to the property and found an unfortunate woman lying lifeless. The master
                    had cruelly castigated her, and she had expired under the lashes. To ascertain
                    whether the corpse was still alive, the cruel master went so far as to pierce
                    his victim's belly with a hot iron. The courts are investigating the case, but
                    the colonist accused of the crime is on the run. The new governor, <tei-persName ref="#EH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName>, has hastened to send details of this act of
                    colonial monstrosity to the Ministry of the Navy.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">It is to be hoped that, in the interests of justice and humanity, such crimes
                    will not go unpunished. The honor of the government and the salvation of the
                    colony are at stake; for where the reign of justice ceases, the right of might
                    and violence is born. </tei-p>
            </tei-div>
            <tei-div xml:id="france" id="france" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">FRANCE.</tei-head>
                <tei-head data-origname="head">PARIS.</tei-head>
                <tei-head data-origname="head">CONVOCATION OF THE CHAMBERS.</tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">The following ordinance is published in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> of <tei-date data-origname="date">July 1</tei-date>, dated
                        <tei-date data-origname="date">June 30</tei-date> and countersigned by <tei-persName ref="#THI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr.
                        Thiers</tei-persName> : </tei-p>
                <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Art. 1. The provision of our ordinance of May 25 of this year, which convened
                        the Chamber of Peers and the Chamber of Deputies for August 20, 1834, is
                            revoked.<tei-pb n="29" facs="v1n1p29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>Art. 2. The Chamber of Peers and the
                        Chamber of Deputies are convened for the next July 31.</tei-p></tei-q>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title> publishes immediately after, but in the
                    non-official section, the following communication which explains the
                    significance of this measure:</tei-p>
                <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">The meeting of the chambers was scheduled for August 20th next. It is now
                        brought forward and set, by this day's ordinance, to July 31st. The king,
                        who in August will be traveling to the southern provinces he has not yet
                        visited, did not want to be absent at the time of the chambers' assembly.
                        Furthermore, this assembly does not have its usual importance: it is
                        convened for the execution of Article 42 of the Charter. However, the
                        government cannot and should not commence their work at that time; no bills,
                        no budget proposals could be ready. Besides, our parliamentary traditions
                        fix the period for the chambers' work between the months of December and
                        May, during the winter season. To begin them in the middle of summer would
                        be an unfortunate departure from established customs. Three hundred deputies
                        from the former chamber, now part of the new one, have already spent five
                        months in Paris this year and could hardly return in July. It is, therefore,
                        appropriate to postpone the work to the customary time. Consequently, after
                        convening the chambers on July 31 and having them in session, the king,
                        using the right of prorogation, will prorogue them until the end of the year
                        to begin the important work of the new legislature at that time.</tei-p></tei-q>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Proroguing the chambers before they are constituted would be another outrage to
                    add to all those we witness daily. The chambers cannot be prorogued before the
                    new powers of the deputies are verified. If this violation of the Charter were
                    to occur, we will return to this subject.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>
            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">ELECTORAL NEWS.</tei-head>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">We believe it is necessary to inform about the election to the new legislature of
                    deputies who have always taken a particular interest in colonial issues.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#AD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. DELABORDE</tei-persName> was elected both in
                        <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Étampes (Seine-et<tei-pb n="30" facs="v1n1p30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>Oise)</tei-placeName>. Undoubtedly, one might wish for a bit
                    more severity from this honorable deputy toward the advisors to the crown.
                    Nevertheless, we will never hesitate to acknowledge Mr. Delaborde's pure
                    intentions, and we are confident that the cause of people of color will always
                    find support and protection in him.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#TRA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. DE TRACY</tei-persName> was elected in two electoral
                    districts in Allier. This choice honors the constituents even more than the
                    representative. Mr. de Tracy is the advocate of all noble causes and, in that
                    capacity, the most genuine and eloquent voice for the oppressed in our
                    colonies.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#FI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. ISAMBERT</tei-persName> was reelected in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Vendée
                        Luçon</tei-placeName>. We congratulate the voters of Luçon for renewing the
                    mandate of the courageous defender of the deportees from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, a man as upright as he is enlightened, who never
                    lets an injustice pass without denouncing it and who has never failed the sacred
                    cause of humanity.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#GdL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. GAETAN DE LA ROCHEFOUCAULD</tei-persName> was elected in the
                    department of Cher. We can only applaud this choice, which sends one of the most
                    zealous champions of the abolition of slavery back to the chamber.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Among the most regrettable losses for people of color in the recent elections, we
                    must first mention <tei-persName ref="#ES" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Eusèbe Salverte</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">5th electoral district of Paris</tei-placeName>, <tei-persName ref="#THI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Thiers </tei-persName> defeated this honorable citizen. It is the
                    victory of intrigue over patriotic austerity personified in the person of Mr.
                    Salverte. Mr. the Minister of the Interior is the pale reflection of <tei-persName ref="#Talle" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. de Talleyrand</tei-persName>, that archetype and patriarch of
                    political roués, just as Mr. Salverte offers us the pure and living image of the
                    virtuous <tei-persName ref="#CAR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Carnot</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#Chara" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Charamaule</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#Meril" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mérilhou</tei-persName> were also not re-elected. Let us hope that the
                    re-elections that will take place due to double nominations will rectify this
                    loss or, rather, this injustice.</tei-p>
                <tei-pb n="31" facs="v1n1p31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
            </tei-div>
            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-head>
                <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">The following article, published by the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> of <tei-date data-origname="date">July 2</tei-date>, is
                        undoubtedly an indirect response to the new information provided about the
                        state of the colony of <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">In a letter dated May 21st, <tei-persName ref="#EH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Vice-Admiral Halgan, Governor
                            of Martinique</tei-persName>, reported to the Minister of the Navy on a tour
                        he had just made to several communes of the colony.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">The following passages are noteworthy in this report: </tei-p>
                    <tei-q data-origname="q">
                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I am happy to report that the population is perfectly calm in all the
                            areas I visited, and everyone is focused on taking advantage of a
                            favorable year for the harvest.</tei-p>
                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I conducted a thorough examination of the internal management of the
                            plantations and the treatment the slaves receive from their masters. The
                            administration generally seemed to me paternal and wise. Punishments are
                            falling into disuse, and on most of the properties where I stopped, I
                            observed that the masters had affection for their slaves who, without
                            concern for the future, are content with the present, attached to their
                            homes, the small comfort they enjoy, and willingly engage in work that
                            does not exceed their physical capabilities.</tei-p>
                    </tei-q>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus, Vice-Admiral Halgan's testimony regarding the situation of the slaves
                        in Martinique is very similar to that of <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Rear-Admiral
                            Dupotet</tei-persName>, whom he replaced, and who himself had merely
                        confirmed the reports of his predecessor on this matter. This unanimity of
                        opinions from individuals holding high positions and who were well-placed to
                        know the truth seems to us of a nature to dispel many unjust prejudices and
                        convince that the lot of the slaves in French colonies today leaves little
                        to be desired for friends of humanity.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Would it not be permissible to point out that this unanimity among the
                        governors might only prove one thing, namely, that they have been, since
                        their arrival,<tei-pb n="32" facs="v1n1p32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>influenced by the same factors? And
                        as for Mr. Halgan in particular, who has barely arrived on the island, who
                        has seen but a few plantations, and who dismisses the pleas presented to
                        him, he is an authority that can, at this point, be challenged.</tei-p></tei-q>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">(<tei-emph data-origname="emph">Messager</tei-emph>.)</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">If one is to believe the official newspaper, wouldn't the slaves be in a real
                        <tei-emph data-origname="emph">el dorado</tei-emph>, enjoying the tranquil and pure happiness that is
                    only found in the shepherds' tales of Durfé and Florian? One must truly lack
                    shame to advance such obviously false claims. Let the
                            <tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title> then provide us with
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Admiral Halgan</tei-persName>, report without reservations, and let it
                    tell us whether the masters mentioned by the admiral as having murdered slaves
                    are cherished by those who have witnessed the mutilation of their brothers. We
                    call for the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">complete and unaltered report</tei-emph>, but they dare not
                    present it in its entirety, for it would suffice to reveal the extent of the
                    slaves' happiness. In an upcoming issue, we will examine this report and address
                    the <tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title>'s deliberate omissions.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>
            <tei-div xml:id="coloniesfr" id="coloniesfr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-head>
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">CAYENNE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">We receive the following letter from <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>,
                    containing considerations on the electoral law, the importance of which our
                    readers will understand.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">The colonial legislation published in <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guiana</tei-placeName>,</tei-q> it says, <tei-q data-origname="q">is the subject of numerous complaints.
                        Men of color have found truel disappointment in the electoral law; hence,
                        those who could meet the 200 francs census have shown great indifference in
                        participating in the elections. In contrast, whites have viewed the
                        consecration of their privileges with a deep sense of satisfaction. Since
                        the bill for the abolition of slavery has passed in England, our aristocrats
                        would be willing to introduce two men of color into the colonial council out
                        of sixteen, provided they are obedient individuals with no connection to
                            <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Bissette</tei-persName>, that eternal enemy of colonial
                        interests.</tei-q></tei-p>
                <tei-pb n="33" facs="v1n1p33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">SUPPLEMENT</tei-emph></tei-p>
                <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Finally, they have reached this result, and two men of color have been
                        admitted in the council, which is nothing but a true mockery, as one knows
                        what influence they can have in deliberations. This de facto exclusion of
                        men of color is a consequence of the exaggerated elevation of the electoral
                        census, which has been designed in such a way as to keep them away.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">To be convinced of this, one need only look at the list of voters,
                        established on October 13, 1833, for <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">French
                        Guiana</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                    <tei-table data-origname="table">
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell role="label" data-origname="cell" data-origatts="role">Electors</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell role="label" data-origname="cell" data-origatts="role">Whites</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell role="label" data-origname="cell" data-origatts="role">Men of color</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">1st district City de Cayenne</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">85</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">66</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">19</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">2nd - Cayenne Island, Canal and Tour de-l'lle.</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">57</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">55</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">2</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">3rd - Districts Tonnégrande and Mont-Sinéry.</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">21</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">12</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">9</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">4th - Districts de Rouza and la Comté.</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">20</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">18</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">2</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">5th - Macouria, Kouron Synamary, Iracoula.</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">38</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">33</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">5</tei-cell>
                        </tei-row>
                        <tei-row data-origname="row">
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">6th - Kair, Approuague, Oyapock.</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">24</tei-cell>
                            <tei-cell data-origname="cell">19</tei-cell>

                    </tei-table>
                </tei-q>
            </tei-div>
            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">MARTINIQUE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">The magistrates who are to compose the assize court in the Grand'Anse case are:
                        <tei-persName ref="#PER" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Perrinelle</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#RL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">RICHARD-LUCY</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#LePell" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Le
                        Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>. Certainly, to transform innocent individuals
                    into guilty ones, one could not have chosen better than these eternal judges
                    under all regimes.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Perrinelle, in the infamous 1824 trial, was one of the three judges out of
                    twelve who voted for the death penalty. RICHARD LUCY, the prosecutor-general at
                    that time, carried out the judgment that sentenced them to perpetual hard labor
                    and branding, in disregard of the appeal to cassation by the condemned. Mr. Le
                    Pelletier-Duclary, a troubled mind, presided, requesting the application of the
                    penalty dictated by his colleague RICHARD-LUCY.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">If one still needs further proof of the morality of this case, suffice it to name
                    the two colonial counselors, Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#JorLa" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">MM. Jorna
                        Lacalle</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#ABour" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Alphonse Bourke</tei-persName>,
                    who rendered the order<tei-pb n="34" facs="v1n1p34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>for the trial before the
                    assizes. Mr. Jorna Lacalle voted for the death penalty in the 1824 case. This
                    magistrate is utterly incompetent. Mr. Alphonse Bourke never completed his law
                    degree, but in the 1824 trial, he voted for the penalty of perpetual hard labor,
                    and as a conscientious judge, he personally ensured the execution of the
                    judgment to which he had contributed. His victims, bound to the stake, could
                    easily see him from one of the windows of the house of his godmother, Mme
                    Duclésemur, where he was stationed.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">-On May 19th, the drawing of lots was carried out for the four assessors who will
                    sit on the assize court. They are: Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#Baud" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Baudin</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#HuyD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Huygues-Despointes</tei-persName>,
                        <tei-persName ref="#DuDu" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Duval-Dugué</tei-persName> (of Grand'Anse) and <tei-persName ref="#Germa" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Germa</tei-persName>. Mr. Duval-Dagué is a complainant and a key
                    witness in the case he is called to judge. The indictment states, on page 39,
                    that two of the accused looted rum on his plantation. The accused were unable to
                    have him recused because Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#AuA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Aubert-Armard</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Aubert-Armand</tei-corr></tei-persName>, the
                    public prosecutor, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Selles</tei-persName>, the royal judge, did not
                    find any incompatibility in a white man judging blacks and mulattos while being
                    a complainant and a witness.<tei-emph data-origname="emph">The respective character of Assessor
                        Duval-Dugué and the accused precludes any idea of recrimination between
                        them...</tei-emph></tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">-When the accused from Grand'Anse were transferred from the prison to the
                    courthouse for the drawing of lots for the assessors, an extraordinary
                    deployment of troops took place; sentinels placed every ten paces prevented any
                    gathering. Leading were Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#LTelem" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Léonce</tei-persName> and
                        <tei-persName ref="#ATelem" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Arthur Télémaque</tei-persName>, handcuffed like all
                    their co-accused. An escort of eighty gendarmes was formed, and two companies of
                    riflemen brought up the rear.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">-<tei-persName data-origname="persName"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Mr. Armand Aubert</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">M.
                    Aubert-Armand</tei-corr></tei-persName>, the public prosecutor in Saint-Pierre, no doubt
                    wanting to show his bias towards men of color, pursues them with a series of
                    petty and miserable harassments, certain signs of a narrow and petty mind. This
                    magistrate pushes the limits of propriety to the point of refusing the titles of
                        <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Mr.</tei-emph> and <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Mrs.</tei-emph> to the relatives of the defendants in
                    the Grand'Anse case who requested from him permission to see the unfortunate
                    prisoners. It seems that the colonial atmosphere has a powerful effect on
                    Europeans predisposed to vanity, as they quickly adopt such ridiculous and silly
                    attitudes.</tei-p>
                <tei-pb n="35" facs="v1n1p35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Shortly after the July Revolution, this same magistrate, appointed royal judge in
                        <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>, did not hesitate to seek advice
                    from one of the representatives of people of color in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>. He wanted, he said, to enlighten himself in order to
                    enforce the laws despite the ill will of the colonists. At that time, it is
                    true, he often met this representative in the salons of the Minister of Justice,
                    where he was received. This explains many things.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GUADELOUPE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">The political situation remains the same; however, there is more tranquility,
                    which probably results less from the satisfaction of the parties than from the
                    weariness they feel from these continuous and fruitless clashes. There has been,
                    therefore, a sort of truce during which young white and colored people have come
                    closer, shaken hands, and mutually promised to live as brothers from now on. May
                    this commitment endure!</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The colonial council has not formulated a single decree; it has, until now, only
                    engaged in opposition to the proposed improvements. Thus, the government,
                    foreseeing that it will be overwhelmed sooner or later by this new institution,
                    is not very pleased with it.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The consolidation of the National Guard remains a question; the council has not
                    yet made any decisions on this matter.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">BOURBON.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The situation in this colony is beginning to feel the effects of some
                    improvements made to the colonial system since the July Revolution. Caste
                    prejudices are decreasing and will eventually disappear as institutions receive
                    further development.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">There is hope that in the upcoming elections, people of color will be appointed
                    to the general council. Already, a large number of votes are assured in favor of
                        <tei-persName ref="#LEl" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Louis Elie</tei-persName>, who enjoys great respect in
                    the country.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">There is some activity in the organization of militias, and, in general, there is
                    no reason to complain about local authorities. As for trade, it is virtually
                    non-existent, and prospects for the future are quite bleak. <tei-pb n="36" facs="v1n1p36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> The re-election of <tei-persName ref="#SUB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr.
                        Sully-Brunet</tei-persName>, as a delegate, which seemed doubtful, now appears
                    to be assured.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ALGER.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">This important possession, whose colonization we hope not to be delayed much
                    longer, is beginning to enjoy some advantages - the inevitable results of its
                    geographical position and the fertile land that extends from the sea to the
                    foothills of the Atlas Mountains. The cessation of hostilities by the indigenous
                    people, renewed confidence, and more active commercial transactions are the
                    first outcomes of a fairer administration; indeed, justice is the primary good
                    for any people, even the barbarians themselves sacrifice at its altars. So what
                    benefits will France gain from this beautiful colony if the government manages
                    it with the broad and philanthropic principles that alone can foster unity
                    between the conquered and the conqueror!</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#BEO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ben-Omar</tei-persName>, the former bey of
                        <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Titeri</tei-placeName>, remains our faithful ally, and more powerful
                    than armies, his conciliatory and wise words make us new allies or strengthen
                    the peaceful disposition of those we have acquired.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#BZ" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ben-Zegri</tei-persName>, a defector from Constantine, and the
                    Jew Narboni, schemers who played a significant role during previous
                    administrations, are now entirely disgraced and have lost the positions they
                    managed to retain under all regimes. Upon hearing this news, the Atlas Mountains
                    Arabs have shown willingness to draw closer to us, which they did not do
                    previously.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">So, France should hasten to organize this beautiful colony, and above all, not
                    forget this great principle: the art of governing is not the art of
                    oppression.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div xml:id="coloniesetr" id="coloniesetr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT-THOMAS.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">If the colonial aristocracy contented itself with persecuting the men of color
                    they deem dangerous, they would only partly fulfill their mission; they must
                    also pursue, even in foreign lands, the unfortunate individuals who have
                    incurred their animosity. Aristocratic <tei-pb n="37" facs="v1n1p37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>hatreds are as
                    tenacious as those of kings, and just as <tei-persName ref="#NIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Nicnolas</tei-persName> pursues the remnants of Poland worldwide, or <tei-persName ref="#C-A" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Charles-Albert</tei-persName> claims his victims everywhere, colonial
                    aristocracy also roars with fury when an unfortunate soul condemned to the
                    executioner manages to escape it. Their minions track down such individuals
                    everywhere, and if treaties, which they can render as flexible as laws, provide
                    a means, extradition satisfies their thirst for mulatto blood and their
                    obsession with punishment.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">After the events of the Grand'Anse, a man of color, <tei-persName ref="#AHav" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr.
                        Auguste Havre</tei-persName>, took refuge on the Danish island of <tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Thomas</tei-placeName>, espérant y trouver un asile où ses
                    persécuteurs ne viendraient pas le troubler. Son erreur était grande !
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Morin</tei-persName>, the son of a pharmacist from <tei-placeName ref="#StP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>, went to Saint Thomas, recognized him,
                    and this young colonist reported him as a supporter of the Grand'Anse revolution
                    to <tei-persName ref="#MACK" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Admiral Mackau</tei-persName>, Admiral Mackau, the
                    commander of the Antilles station, who happened to be in that Danish colony at
                    the time. This admiral who, for good reasons, shares colonial prejudices,
                    requested the extradition of Mr. Auguste Havre in order to hand him over to the
                    authorities in Martinique. He may well obtain it from the Danish government
                    which, despite its usual gentleness, may be influenced by the fear of
                    displeasing the French Ministry of the Navy.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">However, one must hope that the Saint Thomas government will be dignified enough
                    not to sacrifice the peace and lives of the unfortunate individuals who come to
                    its shores to the demands of a faction. Where would we be if the sacred laws of
                    hospitality could be violated with impunity?</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT-LUCIA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">Before his departure from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, former
                    Governor <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dupotet</tei-persName> solicited the extradition of
                    several of the accused in the Grand'Anse conspiracy who had taken refuge on the
                    island of <tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Lucia</tei-placeName> offering to exchange
                    these unfortunate individuals for several escaped slaves from Saint Lucia. The
                    English governor responded with dignity, stating that he did not accept the
                    proposition and that he could not do so without the consent of his government.
                    He believed too highly in the British ministry to entertain the notion that they
                    would support such a dishonest action. Shortly <tei-pb n="38" facs="v1n1p38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>after,
                    when this governor had passed away, Mr. Dupotet did not hesitate to repeat his
                    request with his successor. Such measures can only be conceived by minds
                    accustomed to sycophantic servility, which, likening humans to properties,
                    believe that governments can trade, sell, or barter them at their whim. However,
                    nothing here should be surprising; it is known that Admiral Dupotet, like all
                    the minor colonial despots in charge of exploiting the colonies, is united in
                    heart, affection, and interest with the privileged class in these regions.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#DOM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">DOMINICA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-placeName ref="#DOM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Dominica</tei-placeName>, formerly a French colony but now part
                    of <tei-placeName ref="#GB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Great Britain</tei-placeName> is, of all the Caribbean
                    islands, the one where color prejudices have the least hold. One could even say
                    that they no longer exist since people of color hold public office just like
                    whites, without any rivalry between them except that of merit. It's not
                    surprising, therefore, that this hospitable island, which is also adjacent to
                        <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, Martinique, is a refuge for our
                    unfortunate compatriots who are persecuted. Well, General <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dupotet</tei-persName>, former governor of Martinique, has also made an offer
                    to the governor of this colony for a deal in human flesh. Like his counterpart
                    in <tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Lucia</tei-placeName>, the latter has categorically
                    refused. Honorable people can be found everywhere.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>

            <tei-div xml:id="necrologie" id="necrologie" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                <tei-head data-origname="head">NECROLOGY.</tei-head>
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-persName ref="#LaF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">THE GENERAL LAFAYETTE</tei-persName></tei-head>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">Among the defenders of humanity, the most steadfast, unquestionably the most
                    virtuous, and the most dedicated was <tei-persName ref="#LaF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Lafayette</tei-persName>.
                    He is no more! He passed away on May 20th from an illness he contracted while
                    attending the funeral procession of the unfortunate Dulong. Despite experiencing
                    some signs of illness himself, the old general insisted on being present and
                    followed him devoutly, on foot, from the mortuary house to the grave prepared to
                    receive the mortal remains of <tei-pb n="39" facs="v1n1p39" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>our dear friend. The
                    death of Dulong hastened Lafayette's own demise. For those of us who loved the
                    young deputy and had the privilege of closely observing the admirable old age of
                    the illustrious friend of <tei-persName ref="#WAS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Washington</tei-persName>, this was a
                    double source of sorrow.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The name of Lafayette will live as long as the selflessness of personal interests
                    and pure, unwavering devotion to the cause of all are honored among men. Born
                    into one of the oldest families in France and recently married to Madame de
                    Noailles, a sudden transformation occurred in the excellent nature of this young
                    French nobleman that permanently converted him to the democratic cause. It was
                    like a revelation from above that determined the course of his life. He was but
                    seeking a field where he could worthily employ his noble faculties when news of
                    the American insurrection arrived in Europe. The young husband of Madame de
                    Noailles, the dashing cavalier whose grace and elegant manners were praised at
                    Versailles, had hardly read the American Declaration of Independence before he
                    was won over. Reading the Bill of Rights turned Mr. de Lafayette into what we
                    have seen him become: an indefatigable advocate for the oppressed, without
                    regard to nationality or color, and the most sincere and ardent proponent of
                    universal freedom.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The intrepid volunteer arrived with incredible joy on the soil where he was about
                    to shed his blood, where <tei-persName ref="#JEF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jefferson</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#ADA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Adam</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Adams</tei-corr></tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#WAS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Washington</tei-persName> awaited him, and he only returned after
                    ensuring, along with his illustrious friends, through the surrender at Yorktown
                    that ended the War of Independence in October 1781, the national existence of
                    the great and serene republic that was always the object of his strong and
                    patriotic affection.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The political life of Mr. Lafayette is well-known: the generous role he played in
                    the 1789 revolution, the strength of his logic, the simple clarity, and the
                    unwavering faith with which he advocated, in the <tei-orgName ref="#AN" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">National
                        Assembly</tei-orgName> and the <tei-orgName ref="#AC" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">Constituent
                    Assembly</tei-orgName>, the sacred principles for which we fight, do not need to be
                    reiterated. More than once, he raised his voice against the enslavement of black
                    people and the injustice that excluded people of color from the exercise of
                    their civic rights, but unfortunately, often without success.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In this regard, he did not limit himself to theory; he also added practice, a
                    rarer thing: starting in 1791, the General emancipated all the <tei-pb n="40" facs="v1n1p40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>slaves in his possessions in <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">French
                        Guiana</tei-placeName>. And on this account, he should be particularly dear to
                    black people and people of color, for whom he never ceased to demand freedom and
                    all the privileges of white citizens.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In that same year, <tei-date data-origname="date">1791</tei-date>, he spoke these memorable words from the
                    podium: <tei-q data-origname="q">According to the decrees of the National Assembly, I believe it is
                        clear that free <tei-emph data-origname="emph">men</tei-emph>, property owners, cultivators, and
                        taxpayers are <tei-emph data-origname="emph">citizens</tei-emph>. Now, men of color are property owners,
                        cultivators, taxpayers; are they <tei-emph data-origname="emph">men</tei-emph>? </tei-q>(Barely restrained
                    applause. He continued with the subtle irony that was familiar to him): <tei-q data-origname="q">For
                        my part, I believe they are; and it is to express my opinion that I have
                        requested the floor.</tei-q>At this point, the audience could no longer contain
                    themselves, and applause and cheers drowned out the speaker's voice.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In the committee that was tasked, after the July Revolution, with examining a
                    bill on the same issue, and which only produced the imperfect law that governs
                    us, he displayed the greatest zeal for the extension of political rights for men
                    of color. However, the stubbornness and narrow prejudices of his colleagues
                    paralyzed his goodwill.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Throughout his long career, concerning general politics, Mr. Lafayette made
                    mistakes on occasion; in particular, he allowed himself to be deceived. We
                    regret that he let slip, for the good of mankind, the few beautiful
                    opportunities that presented themselves to him to settle everything according to
                    his principles in the affairs of France and consequently in those of the entire
                    world. But, despite all, it must be acknowledged that no man has, with a more
                    noble character, followed a more honorable and upright course of conduct, even
                    in the face of some apparent contradictions. Perhaps Lafayette alone, among
                    historical figures, has managed to give practical and positive reality to what
                    is meant by the sacred word <tei-q data-origname="q">virtue</tei-q>.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">HERHAN PRINT SHOP, 380, RUE SAINT-DENIS.</tei-p>
            </tei-div>
        </tei-body>
        <tei-back data-origname="back">
            <tei-noteGrp xml:id="RdCv1n1-notes" id="RdCv1n1-notes" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n4F2A" id="n4F2A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">This notion of “fusion” appears frequently in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, notably in article in the December 1834 issue entitled “Of the fusion of the two races in the colonies and the causes that delay it” (“De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent,” <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>, December 1834, 1-7). As Marlene Daut has noted, for the "society of men of color" at the helm of the journal, this notion of fusion remains inextricable from the history of sexual violence that racial mixing implied, in practice, in the colonial context.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Bongie, Chris. <tei-title data-origname="title">Islands and Exiles: The Creole Identities of Post/colonial Literature</tei-title>. Stanford: Stanford University Press, 1998, 274-275.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Daut, Marlene L. <tei-title data-origname="title">Tropics of Haiti</tei-title>, Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 2015. 345‑372.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Manchuelle, François. "The role of the West Indians in the emergence of cultural nationalism in French-speaking black Africa," <tei-title data-origname="title">Cahiers d'Études Africaines</tei-title> 32, no. 127, 1992, 375-408.</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette notion de « fusion » revient souvent dans la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, qui lui consacre, notamment, un article intitulé « De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent » (décembre 1834, p. 1-7). Proposée comme moyen d’abolir la hiérarchie raciale des colonies par le métissage, elle peut paraître utopique, voire naïve. Comme l’a signalé Marlene Daut, elle demeure néanmoins ancrée, pour Bissette et ses associés, dans une conscience nécessaire des rapports de force profondément inégalitaires que le métissage impliquait, en pratique, dans le contexte colonial.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Bongie, Chris. <tei-title data-origname="title">Islands and Exiles: The Creole Identities of Post/colonial Literature</tei-title>, Stanford, Californie : Stanford University Press, 1998, p. 274-275.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Daut, Marlene L. <tei-title data-origname="title">Tropics of Haiti</tei-title>, Liverpool : Liverpool University Press, 2015, p. 345‑372.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Manchuelle, François. « Le rôle des Antillais dans l’apparition du nationalisme culturel en Afrique noire francophone », <tei-title data-origname="title">Cahiers d'Études Africaines</tei-title> 32, no. 127, 1992, p. 375‑408.</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
    </tei-noteGrp>
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n13FA" id="n13FA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The form of the “review,” a non-daily periodical offering a survey of current events, commentary, and reprinted material, originates in Romantic-era English print culture. As indicated by the designation “compendium” in the subtitle, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title> is a compilation of various texts selected by the editors as representative of the political, administrative, legal and cultural news of the colonial world. In choosing the form of the “review” (in the sense of survey or evaluation), the journal indicates its aim to summarize the significant occurrences of the previous weeks.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Like most publications of its kind, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, printed in-octavo, with single column pages, in relatively long issues (40 to 50 pages), more closely resembles a book than a newspaper. Issues are designed to be bound at the end of each year in order to be collected as volumes, as evidenced by the continuous numbering of the pages between issues, beginning in the second year of the journal's print run.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Though making the metropolitan French reader aware of the hardships experienced by people of color, free or enslaved, was the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>'s main objective, it also aimed to promote the literary, artistic, and cultural contributions of contemporaneous writers and historical figures of color. It did so through regular features and reprints, hence the insistence, in the subtitle, on “customs” and “instruction.”</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Printed regularly over the first two years, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> was, thereafter, subject to occasional interruptions until its final issue in June 1842.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Saminadayar-Perrin, Corinne. <tei-title data-origname="title">Les Discours du journal Rhétorique et médias au XIXe siècle (1836-1885).</tei-title> Saint-Etienne: Presses de l'Université de Saint-Etienne, 2007.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Thérenty, Marie-Ève. “Le recueil contre la revue.” <tei-title data-origname="title">Recherches & Travaux</tei-title> 70 (2007): 29-38.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Loué, Thomas. “La revue ” in <tei-title data-origname="title">La civilisation du journal - histoire culturelle et littéraire de la presse française au xixe siècle</tei-title>. Edited by Dominique Kalifa, Philippe Régnier and Marie-Ève Thérenty. Paris: Nouveau Monde, 2011. 333-357</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Berthier, Pascal. “ Miroirs des littératures du monde : les revues parisiennes, 1830-1835.” <tei-title data-origname="title">Romantisme</tei-title> 89 (1995): 7-27</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Portebois, Yannick and Dorothy E. Speirs. <tei-title data-origname="title">Entre le livre et le journal</tei-title>, 2 vols. Lyon: ENS Éditions, 2013.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Jeune, Simon. “Les revues littéraires,” in <tei-title data-origname="title">Histoire de l’édition française</tei-title>, tome 3. Edited by Roger Chartier and Henri-Jean Martin. Paris: Fayard / Cercle de la Librairie, 1990. 455 .</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies </tei-title>souscrit pleinement à la mode, importée d’Angleterre dans les années 1800, des périodiques non-quotidiens destinés essentiellement à une élite lettrée. Comme l’indique la désignation « recueil » dans le sous-titre, il s’agit d’une compilation de textes divers sélectionnés par le directeur comme représentatifs de l’actualité politique, administrative, juridique, et culturelle du monde colonial. La forme éditoriale de la revue (de son étymologie anglaise, <tei-title data-origname="title">review</tei-title>, c’est-à-dire, bilan ou récapitulatif) vise en effet, autant par sa structure que par sa périodicité, à faire la synthèse des événements marquants des semaines écoulées.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>s’attache également à sensibiliser le lecteur métropolitain aux conditions de vie des populations de couleur, libres ou esclavisées, des territoires coloniaux ainsi qu’à promouvoir l’apport culturel, littéraire et artistique d’auteurs et personnalités de couleur avec des rubriques spécialisées, d’où l’insistence du sous-titre sur les « moeurs » et l’« instruction ».</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Comme toutes les publications de son genre, la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>répond plus du livre que du journal par son format (grand in-octavo), sa mise en page traditionnelle et la taille, relativement conséquente, de ses livraisons (de 40 à 48 pages). Celles-ci sont d’ailleurs destinées à être reliées en fin d’année afin d’être recueillies, comme des livres, dans les bibliothèques, ainsi qu’en atteste la numérotation continue des pages, introduite dès le second volume. Régulier au cours des deux premières années, le tirage de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>sera sujet, par la suite, à des interruptions ponctuelles jusqu’à l’arrêt définitif de sa publication en juin 1842.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Saminadayar-Perrin, Corinne. <tei-title data-origname="title">Les Discours du journal Rhétorique et médias au XIXe siècle (1836-1885).</tei-title> Presses de l'Université de Saint-Etienne, 2007.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Thérenty, Marie-Ève.« Le recueil contre la revue », <tei-title data-origname="title">Recherches & Travaux</tei-title>, 70 | 2007, 29-38.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Loué, Thomas. « La revue », dans Dominique Kalifa, Philippe Régnier et Marie-Ève Thérenty (dirs.), La civilisation du journal - histoire culturelle et littéraire de la presse française au xixe siècle, Paris, Nouveau Monde, 2011, p. 333-357;</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Berthier, Pascal. « Miroirs des littératures du monde : les revues parisiennes, 1830- 1835 », Romantisme, n° 89, 1995</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Portebois, Yannick et Dorothy E. Speirs. <tei-title data-origname="title">Entre le livre et le journal</tei-title>, 2 vols. Lyon: ENS Éditions, 2013.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Jeune, Simon. « Les revues littéraires », <tei-title data-origname="title">Histoire de l’édition française</tei-title>, Roger Chartier et Henri-Jean Martin dir., Paris, Fayard / Cercle de la Librairie, 1990, tome 3, p.455 .</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
    </tei-noteGrp>
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6CEA" id="n6CEA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">This claim is indicative of the editorial politics of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> in its early days. Though the ultimate goal remains the abolition of slavery and the dismantlement of the colonies' segregationist order, Bissette and his associates adopt an overhwelmingly assimilationist and conciliatory position with regard to metropolitan France. This may be a pragmatic decision, given the slim possibility of independence for the Caribbean colonies, in the decade that saw France extend its empire to Algeria. The position Bissette adopts throughout the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s print run is, thus, ostensibly that of a colonial and imperial subject who does not see the need to pursue any alternative forms of governance.</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette phrase apporte un éclairage essentiel sur la politique éditoriale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>à ses débuts. Si l’objectif est de combattre le système esclavagiste en commençant, en premier lieu, par le démantèlement de l’ordre ségregationniste des colonies par la revendication des droits civiques des personnes de couleur libres, la voie choisie par Bissette et ses associés dans cette première livraison est, que ce soit pour des raisons idéologiques sincères ou pour des raisons stratégiques, celle de la conciliation et de l’assimilationnisme social. Il n’y est, par ailleurs, pas question d’envisager une quelconque indépendance des Antilles, et ce particulièrement dans une décennie qui voit la France étendre son empire à l’Algérie après avoir perdu plusieurs territoires de son premier empire colonial. La perspective que Bissette affiche par le biais de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> reste celle d’un Français qui croit à la vitalité de l’Empire et n’envisage pas d’alternative au système colonial.</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
    </tei-noteGrp>
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n79DB" id="n79DB" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Unlike the more explicitly emancipatory tracts that Bissette and his associates Fabien and Richard had drafted over the previous two years, this declaration suggests a more conciliatory approach, likely out of concern for attracting and maintaining subscribers, but also, potentially, for fear of official censorship or legal repercussions. A year later, the first issue of the second volume features markedly more radical abolitionist arguments.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">
                <tei-ref target="" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">July 1835</tei-ref>
            </tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Si Bissette et ses associés Fabien et Richard avaient rédigé, au cours des deux années précédentes, plusieurs textes et pétitions à visée explicitement émancipatrice, cette déclaration suggère une approche plus conciliante, sans doute par souci d’attirer un nombre important d’abonnés, mais aussi, potentiellement, par crainte de censure officielle ou de répercussions juridiques. Un an plus tard, la première livraison du second volume tient un discours bien plus explicitement et résolument abolitionniste.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">
                <tei-ref target="" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Juillet 1835</tei-ref>
            </tei-p>
        </tei-note>
    </tei-noteGrp>
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6ED7" id="n6ED7" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">This oxymoron underlines the paradoxical attitude the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> adopts regarding France's imperial and colonial project. Bissette's liberalism does not explicitly extend from anti-slavery to anti-colonialism. However, the apparent adhesion, even “devotion,” of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> to the French empire, is not without complication, particularly in its discussion of the <tei-ref target="" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">bill for immediate abolition published the following year</tei-ref>. France is invoked there, in the spirit of pragmatism, as the necessary arbiter for the transition from “the old to the new state produced by the abolition of slavery,” in a clear allusion to the economic and diplomatic embargo of Haiti in the aftermath of its independence. (July 1835, 10)</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Cet oxymore souligne l’attitude paradoxale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> et de son rédacteur quant au projet colonial. Comme beaucoup de ses contemporains, le libéralisme de Bissette, même lorsqu’il est au plus explicite dans ses engagements antiesclavagistes et antiségrégationnistes, n’est jamais explicitement décolonial. Toutefois, l’apparente adhésion, voire la « dévotion » de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> au modèle colonial, mérite d’être nuancée, notamment par les propos tenus dès l’année suivante, dans <tei-ref target="" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">l’article sur le projet de loi pour l’abolition immédiate</tei-ref>. La France y est invoquée, de manière ouvertement pragmatique, au titre d’arbitre nécessaire à la transition de « l’ancien au nouvel état produit par l’abolition de l’esclavage », dans une allusion claire à l’embargo économique et diplomatique d’Haïti aux lendemains de son idépendance. (juillet 1835, p. 10)</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
    </tei-noteGrp>
    <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n2BFD" id="n2BFD" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
        <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">This original expression analogizes the privileged status of white settlers in the colonies to that of Old Regime nobility. In so doing, it echoes the phrase “prejudice of color,” which was used to refer collectively to the various discriminatory measures put in place by colonial ordinances against the free population of color.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Régent, Frédéric. “Préjugé de couleur, esclavage et citoyennetés dans les colonies françaises (1789-1848),” <tei-title data-origname="title">La Révolution française</tei-title> 9 (2015). 1-37.</tei-p>
        </tei-note>
        <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette expression vise à mettre en équivalence le statut privilégié des colons blancs avec celui qui est réservé à la noblesse, et par extension à opérer un parallèle entre la hiérarchie raciale de la société coloniale et celle de l’Ancien Régime.
